channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: South Korea Enters Period of Uncertainty With President’s Impeachment
item.media:description: Ms. Park addressing the nation over the scandal in November. She has been accused of allowing a shadowy confidante, Choi Soon-sil, to exercise remarkable influence on matters including choosing government officials, and of helping Ms. Choi extort tens of millions of dollars from South Korean companies.
item.description: A slowing economy, a growing nuclear threat from North Korea and a more assertive China are some of the challenges facing the country.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: ‘If You Resist, You Get Hurt, or Die’: Filipinos Praise Duterte’s Antidrug Campaign
item.media:description: As the bodies of people suspected of drug involvement pile up in the Philippines, a recent Times article offered a grim portrait. Many readers wrote in to say they support the government’s actions.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The bodies are piling up in the Philippines as President Rodrigo Duterte goes after drug suspects. Readers there react to a Times report on the crackdown.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY MARCUS

item.title: Israel Rabbinical Authorities Promise Clarity in Conversions Abroad
item.description: In a statement, the authorities also said the questionable conversion of Ivanka Trump done in New York would likely be considered legitimate.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Chaos and Desperation as Thousands Flee Aleppo Amid Government Advance
item.media:description: Residents fleeing the violence in Aleppo, Syria, gathered at a government checkpoint in the city on Thursday.
item.description: Hundreds of men are missing amid reports of government reprisals against opposition supporters in rebel-held areas, rights officials said.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Bomb at Checkpoint in Cairo Area Kills 6 Police Officers
item.description: The explosives were detonated next to a large mosque in Giza less than two hours before hundreds flocked to the area for Friday Prayer.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Foes of Russia Say Child Pornography Is Planted to Ruin Them
item.media:description: Vladimir K. Bukovsky in his study at his home in Cambridge, England. Mr. Bukovsky was visited by police officers who had “received information about forbidden images” in his possession, he said.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: A K.G.B. dirty trick known as “kompromat,” the fabrication of compromising or illegal material, may have returned in a particularly noxious form.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Wall Street Is Europe’s Landlord. And Tenants Are Fighting Back.
item.media:description: A local child rode a bike in Tyrrelstown, a suburb northwest of Dublin, where dozens of tenants had been served with eviction notices after being told their homes had been purchased by a Goldman Sachs investment fund.
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.description: Huge profits and dubious tax strategies have made investment firms in America the object of frustration and anger, as many Europeans face eviction and fear becoming homeless.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: Colombia Reports Major Rise in Birth Defect Amid Zika Crisis
item.description: Four times as many babies were born with microcephaly this year as in 2015 in Colombia, home to the second-largest Zika epidemic after Brazil.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Canada Strikes a Deal to Cut Carbon Emissions by Putting a Price on Them
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced a plan to reduce carbon emissions that relies on fossil fuel taxes and cap-and-trade systems of emission allowances.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.category: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs

item.title: The Interpreter: How ‘Islands of Honesty’ Can Crush a System of Corruption
item.media:description: Former President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil, right, and former President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of Argentina at a meeting in São Paulo, Brazil, on Friday.
item.description: With the Parliament in South Korea voting to impeach President Park Geun-hye, the cavalcade of scandals can make it seem like the world’s politicians have suddenly become greedier en masse.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA TAUB

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: With Mass Protests, South Koreans Wield a Familiar Weapon in a New Era
item.media:description: Riot police officers used tear gas to disperse protesting students during violent clashes at Yonsei University in September 1987.
item.description: In 1987, the demonstrations were far more violent than those of today. But the passions of those demanding change still burn bright.
item.dc:creator: SUSAN CHIRA

item.title: Yahya Jammeh, Gambian President, Now Refuses to Accept Election Defeat
item.media:description: President Yahya Jammeh showed his inked finger before voting on Dec. 1. After initially conceding defeat, he reversed course and called for new elections.
item.description: Mr. Jammeh’s rejection of the results of last week’s vote came as a blow to many Gambians, who feared that it would catapult the nation into chaos.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY and JAIME YAYA BARRY
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: With Election Defeat, Ghana’s President Becomes Casualty of Faltering Economy
item.media:description: Nana Akufo-Addo after being declared the winner of Ghana’s presidential election. The election was a referendum on the country’s faltering economy.
item.description: President John Mahama was beaten by Nana Akufo-Addo, a lawyer and former foreign minister who rode a wave of discontent over the country’s plummeting growth rate.
item.dc:creator: SEAN LYNGAAS

item.title: What in the World: Nazi Grave in Brazil Endures as Marker of Secret Plan to Colonize
item.media:description: A Nazi grave marker in a cemetery near Laranjal do Jari, Brazil. The alternate image has been enhanced for legibility, consistent with its original painting.
item.media:credit: Lúcio Costa Leite; Illustration by The New York Times
item.description: Known as the Guyana Project, an expedition to study the Amazon in 1935 turned into the pursuit of a German Guiana, an idea undone by malaria and other troubles.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Xinjiang, Tense Chinese Region, Adopts Strict Internet Controls
item.media:description: A market in Kashgar in the Xinjiang region of China, in 2015. New rules appear to be aimed at criminalizing people in Xinjiang who post online about ethnic conflict.
item.description: The regulations punish people for spreading “false information” in the far western region, which has grappled with ethnic violence.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Japanese Leader’s Pearl Harbor Visit May Not Be a First, After All
item.media:description: Shigeru Yoshida, then the prime minister of Japan, signing a treaty to normalize relations between his country and most of the victorious Allies in San Francisco in 1951. On his way home, he visited Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, home of the United States Pacific Fleet and the target of Japan’s raid in 1941.
item.description: Japan said Shinzo Abe would be the country’s first prime minister to visit the site of the attack, but it now appears that historic occasion actually took place in 1951.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Key Figure in South Korean Leader’s Troubles: A Puppy
item.media:description: Ko Young-tae speaking to members of the media at a prosecutor’s office in Seoul in October. Mr. Ko said he went to the authorities with corruption allegations after an argument over a puppy with an adviser of President Park Geun-hye of South Korea.
item.description: The corruption scandal that engulfed the president, Park Geun-hye, has yet another twist — an argument involving her adviser’s dog.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Paris Imposes Measures to Fight Pollution, With Mixed Results
item.media:description: The Eiffel Tower was shrouded in haze on Thursday as Paris experienced a spike in smog.
item.description: The authorities say a thick layer of haze over the city is the result of car exhaust, wood-burning furnaces and a layer of warm, stagnant air.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Refugee’s Arrest Turns a Crime Into National News (and Debate) in Germany
item.media:description: A memorial in Freiburg, Germany, near Dreisam River, where a medical student was found raped and killed. Reaction was swift and bitter when the police announced last Saturday that they had arrested an Afghan refugee in the case.
item.media:credit: Patrick Seeger/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Questions about how news outlets reported, or didn’t report, on a rape and murder suspect from Afghanistan underscored a rift over Chancellor Angela Merkel’s policy on newcomers.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Canada Today: Emissions Policy, Bird-Hunting and Meat Pie
item.media:description: Jerry Hussey, left, and Shannon Mouland hunting turr, a migratory seabird, off Bonavista, Newfoundland.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau met with leaders to discuss carbon emissions, Canadian women’s golf got a shot in the arm and history was made on a telecast.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.category: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Heroine After a 16-Year Fast, Now Spurned by Many
item.media:description: Irom Chanu Sharmila in 2011 in Imphal, India, 11 years into her nearly 16-year hunger strike to protest abuses by the armed forces.
item.media:credit: Manpreet Romana for The New York Times
item.description: Irom Sharmila was the revered symbol of local resistance to abuses by the armed forces in India until she ended her fast and decided to run for office.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Hong Kong’s Beijing-Backed Leader Says He Will Not Seek Re-election
item.media:description: Hong Kong’s leader, Leung Chun-ying, at a summit meeting in Peru in November. He is the first Hong Kong leader to refrain from seeking re-election since the city returned to Chinese rule in 1997.
item.description: Leung Chun-ying, who has led Hong Kong amid heightened concerns over the erosion of civil liberties, said that a campaign would impose “unbearable stress” on his family.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG

item.title: 14 Countries Press Myanmar to Allow Aid in Rohingya Areas
item.media:description: A Rohingya woman and child who fled Myanmar at a camp in neighboring Bangladesh this month. The United Nations said that close to 22,000 Muslims had arrived in Bangladesh since Nov. 1.
item.description: The countries were “deeply concerned” about a humanitarian crisis in the north of Rakhine State, where a counterinsurgency has sealed off the persecuted Rohingya minority.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Geert Wilders, Dutch Far-Right Leader, Is Convicted of Inciting Discrimination
item.media:description: The far-right Dutch politician Geert Wilders in court on Nov. 23. He was convicted on Friday of inciting discrimination by leading a crowd at a political rally in chanting “fewer, fewer” to the question, “Do you want more or fewer Moroccans in this city and in the Netherlands?”
item.description: Mr. Wilders, who is seen as a likely contender to become prime minister after elections next year, has said that the Netherlands would be safer with fewer Moroccans.
item.dc:creator: NINA SIEGAL
item.category: People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (Netherlands)

item.title: Ashton Carter, U.S. Defense Chief, Makes Unannounced Visit to Afghanistan
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter.
item.description: Mr. Carter, on what is probably his last visit to the country as defense secretary, met with American troops and Afghan leaders.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Only a Rumbling Volcano Could Make North Korea and the West Play Nice
item.media:description: Mount Paektu, on the border between North Korea and China, erupted 1,000 years ago in one of the most violent volcanic explosions in human history.
item.description: Mount Paektu is sacred to the North Korean people. When a swarm of tiny earthquakes were recorded, the reclusive country decided it needed help.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: Iowa Exports Soybeans to China, So Why Not a Whole Farm?
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, then the vice president of China, visiting the farm of Rick and Martha Kimberley near Maxwell, Iowa, in 2012. The property inspired plans to build a “model farm” in northern China.
item.description: A proposed “model farm” in China has highlighted its leader’s long relationship with Iowa and Gov. Terry Branstad, Donald J. Trump’s choice for ambassador.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: After Park, Who? A Guide to Those Who Would Lead South Korea
item.media:description: Hwang Kyo-ahn.
item.description: There is no shortage of contenders to replace President Park Geun-hye of South Korea, who has been suspended from office and may lose her job over a corruption scandal.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Broken Men in Paradise
item.media:description: Benham Satah, an Iranian refugee, in Lorengau, on Manus Island in Papua New Guinea.
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson/VII for The New York Times
item.description: The world’s refugee crisis knows no more sinister exercise in cruelty than Australia’s island prisons.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Making South Africa Great Again
item.media:description: An anti-government march in Pretoria, South Africa, last month.
item.description: As in America, ‘exceptionalism’ can create dangerous myths about a country. But it can also inspire a powerful reform movement.
item.dc:creator: SISONKE MSIMANG

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Bumpy Peace for Colombia
item.media:description: A rally in support of the peace process, a few blocks from where a revised agreement was being signed, in Bogotá, Colombia, last month.
item.description: The FARC is on the way to disappearing as an insurgent armed force, but peace is still uncertain.
item.dc:creator: MARTA RUIZ

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
